turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Jesus, it's too damn bright in here... Like a goddamn spotlight... I'm goin' blind...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: This?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Yeah... too bright...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Roll the hose.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What, are you kidding? By myself?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What, is it the stairs? Christ, I'll let you win next time.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: You got a problem with drilling, probie?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: No, Lt., I don't have a problem with drilling. But let's just have one drill. Not one for the company and one for me.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Roll the hose.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Ready?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Christ, Stephen, let's wait for the hose team...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Listen to it, Brian... Jump when I say... It won't get us.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I waited... I would have fucking waited...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: That's not what it's about, Brian. The point is there was a kid in there. And what if there'd been two? I went in because that's what I do. It's my way. It's dad's way. It isn't everybody's way.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Dad's way? Where did he tell you that? In a fucking seance?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: You said you wanted to know something, Brian. What did you learn today?  What do you say, Brian, huh? Time to move on?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Look, you are sorta making yourself fair game.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Thanks for the insight.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Brian, look --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Just leave me alone, okay?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: ...Not now, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Had to take on another fire bare- handed, huh? Had to be fucking myth man in there instead of looking out for your probie. Is that what happened? Is it, Stephen?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I had that fire. He didn't listen!

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: He didn't listen? He was a fucking candidate! He was your responsibility. He shouldn't have been there in the first place, Stephen.  You burned him.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Fuck you.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Hey, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Just... Just wanted to say hello...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: So hello.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Well, long as you're here you can help clean up a little. I've got a guy coming to look at this in a few minutes.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You're selling dad's boat?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Yeah, it's just another memory in my life right now. And I got way too many of them...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I really should get back. There's... there's something I'm supposed to do.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Yeah? What have you got to do?  Look at you. Look at your face. All the things you must be thinking. Man, you must really hate my guts. Well, you know what? It's okay.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Look, Stephen, maybe we can talk about this some other --

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: -- Okay, so you don't like me. You don't like everything I've done. What, because I wasn't such a genius the way I raised you? Jesus Christ, dad was gone, what was I supposed to do? You tell me, what the fuck was I supposed to do?!

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: It's okay, Stephen, I --

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: -- I tried, y'know? Helen's right. I don't have all the answers, but goddamn it, I've got some.  Look, you're gonna do what you have to, and maybe I shouldn't have gotten in the way. I'm your brother, not your father. Go on. You gotta go somewhere? Go...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I saw it.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Saw what?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: When dad died, I saw another fire...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Everybody did.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I saw it before it got them. I tried to yell, but... He asked me to look out for him. And I didn't do it. I let him die.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: ...Jesus, you been carrying that around for twenty years? For christ's sake, you were seven years old! You think he could have heard you in there?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I hate him so much sometimes, Stephen. You don't know how hard it was for me to put that uniform on...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Maybe I do.  ...What a fuckin' mess, huh?  People can change Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Sometimes right when you're looking at them.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Oh God, Stephen, what's going on with you?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I don't know, Brian... I don't know...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- Stephen, wait a minute. I gotta talk to you. It's Adcox, he's --

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: -- What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I saw Adcox's back! I saw the burn! I put it there! Jesus Christ, Stephen, he's been killing people!

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I knew when you came looking for the chemicals. Looking for me.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- What were they doing there?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: They were for the fucking boat, Brian.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Anything else?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What are we going to do about this?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I'll handle it.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: We gotta go to Rimgale, Stephen.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I'm his Lt. He's my responsibility. I'll handle it. Me.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You're his Lt., Stephen...  Are you gonna handle it? Are you Stephen?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: You crazy son of a bitch, why couldn't you stay behind a desk where you belong?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: "You never know till the fire stares you down if you're gonna be --"

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Oh shut up, huh?  I think I broke my goddamn arm...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Don't tell them about Adcox... Don't let 'em...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I'm sorry... I'm sorry I thought... I won't.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Jennifer.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: You're back.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You look great.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Thanks for calling.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Uh... I've been sorta keeping a low profile... the academy... I graduated today.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: So... I see you're still in the neighborhood.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Not quite. Just visiting. I live in Lincoln Park now.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah? What have you been up to?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I work for city hall.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Really? No kidding.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: What, you think I just dried up and blew away when you left? The world does turn once in awhile Brian, even without your permission.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Well, if nothing else, it's nice to know we can still be friends.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I don't want to be your friend, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: With grenadine, right?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: When I was twenty.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Oooh, very sophisticated. Having fun?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Look, I'm not the same girl who had nothing better to do than wrap her legs around you on a Saturday night. This isn't about fun. I'm working here.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Carrying Swayzak's notebook?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Let me tell you something. Martin Swayzak is going to be this town's next mayor.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah. Swayzak. Humanity's last hope. How can you work for that guy?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Why do you think Marty came here tonight? Because he cares about your department. You don't know how hard he works. You don't know about his programs helping West Side --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- All I know is that his programs are getting firemen hurt.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Bullshit. Marty's plan is only about efficiency. I've got two cousins on the job, you think I'd work for him if I didn't believe in it?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What was that? Oh man, you have picked up a few moves since John Paul II Boulevard.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yeah, well I like to think I'm just a little past hanging out on JP II watching the Irish pick fights and Litwalks barf in the planters.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I seem to remember some pretty good nights on JP II.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Boy, took you all of thirty seconds to blow that.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: C'mon Jennifer, he's just another North-Side jag-off with a mouth.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Brian, do you always have to be so stupid? Think about your future for once.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: So now you suddenly care about my future?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Look, I didn't mean to take a piece out of you back there, I just thought you'd call when you came back. You didn't and...  Don't blow it just because of this garbage between us.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hey, sorry if I made you look bad in front of your boss. But I'm not gonna be a poster boy for him, I'm trying to do something here. There's five hundred smoke eaters in this room that do that stuff for real every day. Tell Swayzak to talk to one of them.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I've been thinking about what you said the other night... If the offer's still on the table, I'd like to talk about it.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: ...Okay. I'll arrange things with your assignment captain.  Marty's a good man, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Arson.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Straightest answer your department's given me all week.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: How's it going?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Boss and I are up to about three words an hour.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Green committed to a thousand.  There's another fund-raising party tonight. Marty'd really like you to come.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I don't know, I'm kinda swamped here.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I could use a date.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah? Well, maybe I can fit it in...

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hey...  So are you dating your boss or what?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: If you weren't at least the 300th person to ask me that, I'd probably be pissed.  Boy, you sure know it's a man's world sometimes...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Sorry.  Are you dating anyone?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: You think that's really any of your business?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Well, you did invite me here.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Marty did.  But I wanted you to come to.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Boy, Rimgale's as slow as a snail, isn't he?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: No, he's more of a dinosaur. Guy's not a dummy, though. He's juggling alot of balls on this one.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yeah, but it doesn't take Albert Einstein just to figure out if these guys were killed by accidents or not.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Jesus, give him a break. There isn't enough proof yet to go public. Sure, we found some chemical shit we think somebody dumped in the plugs to torch 'em, and we've maybe figured out why backdrafts, but you can't rush this stuff. Not 'till it's locked.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: But Rimgale's probably going to come around to arson.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: In a dinosaur kinda way, yeah.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Thanks for the invite.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Got anything to drink in there?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Oh, there might be something stashed away for emergencies.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: This is one of the oldest fire stations in the city. Lotta tradition locked up in here. What do you think?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Homey.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: See that trap door up there? That used to lead to the hay loft when they had horse-drawn engines. It was pretty different then... but kinda the same, y'know?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Do you miss it?  You seem like you do.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: When I came back, I knew more than anything else that I wanted to be a fireman.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Then why did you quit?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I wanted to be a good one.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Well, our specimen here is your basic standard issue piece of primary suppression equipment. This area is the pumping panel, which controls the rate of liquid insertion into the hose.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Brian. What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You told Swayzak about our arson lead. It's all over the fucking news.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I didn't know it was a secret. There aren't supposed to be secrets between the city and its investigators --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- Bullshit! You knew what I told you wasn't ready for the papers --

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Will you please keep your voice down, there's people --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- You could have scared the son of a bitch off. We may never bust him now. All for a couple's political points.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I was doing my job.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah? And just how much of all this has been "doing your job"?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Let me ask you something, do you really think Marty had you assigned to arson because of your firefighting skills? Who the hell are you kidding? I was there, remember? I saw you and your brother --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Leave Stephen out of this --

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Oh yeah, he's the real fireman.  Who are you? Just another probie working for Swayzak --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- I work for the city.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: You knew what we were asking you to do. Don't suddenly pull out a conscience now. The fit isn't right.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: We still talking?  Look, I'm sorry about the other day --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Swayzak knows something about the guys that were murdered. I want to know why he keeps that hidden.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I don't know anything about it.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You could check. It'd be in his files.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Do you know what you're asking me to do?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Y'know, four years ago I was working in a bakery. Two years ago I was bringing Marty coffee and he didn't even know my name. I run that office now. Marty believed in me and I believe in him. You want me to just throw that away?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Your boss is lying, Jennifer.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What is --

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Just take it.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: That's a dumb thing to say.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I think your boss is going to need some spin control.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I quit two days ago, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What'll you do?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: I don't have the slightest idea...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I'll see ya around, huh?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: It's a small town.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Brian McCaffrey...  Oh this is really a treat. Brian McCaffrey. Lost a dad to the animal, huh?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hey, do I know you?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I'm close... but I can't get who it is...

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: So you came to me...  Well, this is going to be an interesting afternoon after all...

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Okay, here's the deal. I'll tell you a story, you tell me one. Fair?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Who's doing this?

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Your first question should be who isn't. It isn't a spark, Brian. Not enough damage. And an insurance pro? Where's the profit margin?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Then who --

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: -- No no, your turn. Tell me a story.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I don't have a story.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Sure you do.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Famous story even. Straight burn. Just an engine and truck first on scene. What did you feel, Brian, when you first got there?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: You gotta tell a story too, Brian. It's fair. C'mon, don't think too hard --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I... I thought it was great. I loved it. It was nothing to these guys... medium deal.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Right. Light smoke, low roll. Couple'a civilians hollering -- medium deal. So young fireman Adcox and Captain McCaffrey, they head up stairs, get out on the fire escape -- McCaffrey does the ballsy jump across... what were you feeling, Brian?  C'mon, you promised. Be honest.  Okay... Guard!

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- I wanted to be him. Right then I wanted to be him more than anything...

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Very good, Brian. -- About your report here. The way to a torch's heart is through his tools. That's how you know him. It's the way he talks to the fire. And to you if you listen.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: The outlets.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: That's a probie answer. You're smarter than that, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Trychticholorate.

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Good. -- So our two heroes, Adcox and McCaffrey, they go back inside. Only there's another fire in there nobody sees. And it took your dad, didn't it Brian? Did you see him burn?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Who the fuck is doing this?

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: After it took your dad... the fire... did it look at you Brian? Did it talk to you?...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Oh Jesus Christ...

turns.speaker: RONALD
turns.text: Not such a far walk after all, is it, Brian?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: If it was a joke, sir, you'd be laughing.

turns.speaker: CHIEF FITZGERALD
turns.text: You walked out on this academy six years ago. One week to graduation. You think we forgot that? You think I did?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I want another shot, Sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF FITZGERALD
turns.text: Look, everybody remembers your old man. Being his son, all you had to do was breathe to graduate here. Dead Hero Father Rule. But you blew us off. Why should I take you back?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: If you remember, sir, my test scores were in the top --

turns.speaker: CHIEF FITZGERALD
turns.text: -- I don't give a damn what your test scores were, maybe you could have been a good firemen, but you had your shot.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I need another one, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF FITZGERALD
turns.text: Sorry, but it's out of my hands. Try again next year.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: No, it isn't out of your hands or you wouldn't even have met me. If I push you have to let me back in. Dead Hero Father Rule. Sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF FITZGERALD
turns.text: Even if you graduate this academy, you've still got nine months of probation. That's hard duty, son. If you don't really love this job, it'll kill you.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: See you Monday. Sir.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Uh, I'm Brian McCaffrey. Your new assistant.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Your Dennis' kid.  I work alone.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Are you still here?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Get used to me, Inspector. I'm not going anywhere.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Then go find a corner. I don't want you in my way.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I think we should get something straight here. I was assigned to this office by the city.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Look, I knew your father, he had a helluva reputation on this job. But that don't mean you get any slack. Swayzak sends you down here, okay, I gotta eat you, that's the rules and I got nothing to say about that. But Swayzak or no, you live with me. Step out of line, and I don't care who knows you, I'll swing the hammer.  You think you're the first?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Pest control.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: -- Shhh.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What are you listening to?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: So you were happy here. Warm and cozy and in no hurry...  Soot high, clean unburned wall low, indicates slow burn in thermal balance.  Find me some glass.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Glass?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Do we have a language barrier here? Glass.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Glass found in ignition room is in small, thin pieces, indicating explosion. Lack of discoloration indicates a long, slow burn. Explosion must of come after a slow burn.  You little tease... What were you up to you little bastard, huh? What made you that mad?  Or scared.  It started in this room. Took its time, hung out... but the air ran out. It couldn't breathe. So it was snuffed. But it wasn't dead... still all that trapped heat, lying low, waiting for some sucker to open the door and give it that one gulp of air...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: -- Another backdraft.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Temperature in this room was about 2000 degrees, but copper wire in outlet is melted, which requires 5000 degrees. An accidental short in the plug could of created a spark of 7000 degrees, hot enough to melt the wire and start a fire.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: No it couldn't.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Uh, I don't think that's in my contract...

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: I just re-wrote your contract. C'mere...

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Read.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: "Trychtichlorate is a binary structured --"

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: -- Go to the bottom. Under heat properties.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: "During heat episodes of 2000 Kelvin or higher, Trych breaks down and dissipates. Will consume magnesium".

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Ever burned magnesium? It's so hot it takes water molecules and BAMM!

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Son of a bitch tears 'em apart just to eat the oxygen. Wouldn't take much at all to melt ten gauge wire. Problem's burnt magnesium leaves a powder trace -- unless you could find something that would eat its residue.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Trychticholorate. Then Swayzak can announce Seagrave was a murder.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Look, it isn't proof, okay? Someone may have put the chemical in the outlet, but we found it as a vapor in Cosgrove's clothes.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: And the putty around the door?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Even if it was used to seal the air off, that doesn't explain why someone would go to the trouble of a backdraft. A gun's a helluva lot easier

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: But the right guess on this is arson.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: I don't guess.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Some people say you don't do much of anything when it comes to this case.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: I don't work for them, either.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: That's it! Oh, that son of a bitch, he's different, goddamn it! You see what this tells us, huh? Our killer doesn't love fire!

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: I got it after we talked to Ronald. Torches. Want to fry the whole goddamn world. But the fires that killed those guys never really burned up much. -- The burns were all lit in outlets surrounded by double firebreaks in the walls. And he made his burns backdrafts.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: But he killed these guys.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: But he could have killed everybody there. The firebreaks kept it from spreading in the wall. The backdraft blew out the flame. That's it. That's the reason.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What reason?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Why backdrafts. Whoever fried Seagrave and Cosgrove went to a helluva lot of trouble to make sure they died by fire, but also made sure the fire blew itself out.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: That's why the sealant on the doors... So what have we got, a torch with a conscience?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: No, we have a stone killer trying to make a point.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Are you going public with this?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: No. Do that and I guarantee you'll scare him off. I don't want him running away.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: What the hell are you doing here?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I'm finished with Swayzak. I'll do whatever you want me to do. I just want to help catch the guy that burned Tim. You gotta give me another shot.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: In a word, Brian, what is this job all about?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Fire.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hey boss, Dekom Trust is owned by Pan Illinois... which is majority controlled by Lakeside Dynamics... which is a division of Windy City Ventures... who's partners are...  Alan Seagrave, Donald Cosgrove, and Jeffrey Holcomb.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Son of a bitch. They knew each other.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: So Seagrave and Holcomb were accountants...

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: And Cosgrove. Coppers figured he laundered money for the mob before getting into real estate. They weren't very high on Seagrave, either.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Nice bunch of guys.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Who all ended up wearing candles for faces...  Swayzak's up to his ass in this somehow. Guy can barely hold a drink in his hand, he's so scared.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: This is the copy of Swayzak's manning report that was released. Everybody on this job knows it's bullshit but we could never argue with the numbers. They're all airtight.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah? Airtight?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I've got three different drafts of the same report -- with different numbers that're all over the place. Looks like they were just making it up as they went along.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Did a little check on the consulting firm that wrote the report. They did exactly one job -- Swayzak's manpower study. It's not even really a company. No employees, no directors, just a PO Box.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Then who wrote the report?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: It had to be someone who knows numbers. Some kind of fancy accountant. But what's the connection?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Well Brian, I guess you can say it's arson now...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: How ya feeling?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Did you pull me out?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Did I say thanks?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Just wondering.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: I hate hospitals. You're so... so goddamn useless...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: So what do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: I've been lying here hours... just thinking... We're close...  We're not looking in the right place, Brian. This one knows us and we're not looking in the right place...

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Your brother was a good man.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Another couple of good men get burned up for their city? Is that how it's going to read?  You're the only one that knows.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Like it never happened...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Brian?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Hi, Helen. Man, you look great.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You look like... Brian.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: 'Bout written you off. How long have you been in town?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Four months.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Four months?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I know, I know, Should'a called. I've been really busy. I joined the fire department.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: That's Sean? Jeez, he's a giant.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yeah, you'd be surprised what three years can do to a kid.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Sean, come on out, man. What, you forget your favorite uncle?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stephen told him you were killed in a hot tub accident.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Well that's two things to strangle Stephen for. Where is he, anyway?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stephen's not staying here now, Brian. He moved out last April.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Oh, man, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You guys ought to try picking up a phone once in awhile.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah. Big fan.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: And I'm a huge fan of what you did to save that woman, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Uh, I think there's been a mistake. I didn't save that woman.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: No need to be modest, Brian.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: No, you don't understand, I saved a mannequin.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: -- That really was incredibly work you did. You and your brother, fighting fires together, helluva image, isn't it? You must feel lucky to be assigned under his command.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Every little boy's fantasy.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: Brian, let me come to the point. I'd like to offer you a job.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I have a job.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: This one's still with the fire department. One of our best investigators, Don Rimgale, is working on a very difficult, visible case right now. We think he could use another pair of hands and you're exactly the kind of guy I want representing us: An authentic hero from a traditional firefighting clan.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah, we got all kinds of traditions -- like dying young.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: Not every job in the fire department comes with a tombstone, Brian. This could be a great opportunity to move... beyond a fire engine.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: Mr. McCaffrey...

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Nice boat.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: It isn't mine.  Let's get a picture.

turns.speaker: SWAYZAK
turns.text: Mr. McCaffrey... Keeping busy?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Yeah. In fact, I just dropped off a letter to the Times explaining how yesterday's arson announcement was a fabrication by your office. They loved it. And you know what? You were right, my family background in firefighting gave it weight.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Completely out of control.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: What the hell are we waiting for?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Aren't you even curious?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Engine 115, right?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: How'd you know? These are supposed to be sealed.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Lucky guess.  And a case of scotch to a captain in station assignments.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: You crooked son of a bitch. Why 115?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Lots of fires. They promote faster there. Take a look at the last Lt.'s list, half the guys on it came from that battalion. Gotta think about your future, Timmy. 115's the station.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Ah man, if you're gonna bribe your way into a station, why not 17 with me and your brother?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Man. Something sure put a crimp in his evening.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Backdraft.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Do you have to do that?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Could you believe that fire? Man! First day! There I was, Adcox and me, pullin' that lady right out of the fire's fuckin' throat! I love it here -- No surround and drown for this company. Fighting 17th! Goddamn Stephen's amazing. You see how he took that fire by the balls? I'm gonna be that good some day, you watch.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Y'know what Stephen said to me, right when all the shit was coming hard? "You never know till the moment the fire stares you down if you're just gonna do this job or be great at it".

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Ah man, is he usin' that line now on you? What, you think he made that little gem up? Jesus Christ, I used to have to listen to my old man use that every morning.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: "Probationary Fireman Brian McCaffrey, on his very first fire, showed the kind of bravery and courage of a veteran firefighter when he risked life and limb to double-check a burning floor alone, emerging victoriously with Anna Rodriguez, a seamstress for the North Shore Clothing Company... McCaffrey first gained prominence as the subject of a 1972 Pulitzer Prize winning photograph taken at the scene of his father's death..."

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: So, you surviving without me?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: There's no replacement 'cause of your boss' cuts, if that's what you mean. If someone else goes out on an injury we're really screwed.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Swayzak's not my boss.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: Well, if it isn't the littlest McCaffrey.  Hey! You break anything with that you buy it!  Sorry, there must be something wrong with my eyes. I keep thinking that's a fire department uniform.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: It's in my blood, Willy.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: Really. Well, let's have a look at what else was "in your blood". I always look forward to getting these, they make such a nice collage for the bar... "Assistant Director, Sales, Aspen Snowmobile Tours..."

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Didn't offer the kinda growth and challenge I need.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: Uh huh. And "Pioneer's Pride, Mobile Log Cabins". That was in your blood about six months wasn't it?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Management were pin heads.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: "Laguna Jamming, Custom Surfboards"?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Coffee sucked.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: And just this year, "Brian's Sound Spectrum". Your own company even. Big step.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: I was ahead of my time.

turns.speaker: WILLY
turns.text: You know, I've got a perfect little spot here for "Brian McCaffrey, Fireman"...

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Who's going to die?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Brian. He's not doing it right, dad. He never does it right.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Well, let's have a look.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Your brother's right. If you don't fasten these correctly they could open and you'd get burned.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: And DIE!

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Fireman shit?

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Hey, what's with the mouth? Where'd you grow up, a barn?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Firehouse.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Cute.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Dad!

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: You've come along a dozen times, Stephen, give your brother a chance. We'll be back in a few minutes.  How 'bout it, sport?

turns.speaker: GRINDLE
turns.text: I hate it when we gotta fucking go look for it.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Call in another alarm. We're gonna need some back-up.

turns.speaker: GRINDLE
turns.text: Stevie? Rimgale's here to see you.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I'm busy.

turns.speaker: GRINDLE
turns.text: He just wants to --

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: -- I'm busy goddamn it, okay?

turns.speaker: GRINDLE
turns.text: We gotta roll, Stevie...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I'll be there.

turns.speaker: GRINDLE
turns.text: They're waitin' man.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I'll be there, goddamn it!

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Uh, Helen, I wanted to talk to you a second about Sean...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stephen, I'm kinda busy here, can we talk about this later?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: You can't talk about my brother like that...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Here we go...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stephen, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Fixing my roof.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: It's not your roof anymore.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Where's Sean?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He's got piano lessons.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Oh yeah? How's he doing?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He's going to be a fireman.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Give up, babe. You can't fight it. Believe me, my mom tried...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stephen, you gotta stop just showing up on the roof like this.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I just wanted to, I don't know, not exactly apologize for the other night -- especially since I don't remember much of it --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: -- You remember.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Yeah... I just thought I should say, I don't know, something.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The great communicator.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Sorry I hit Jackson.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He deserved it. He was born deserving it.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: He treats you okay?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I treated you better.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You treated me like shit.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You want some coffee?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Coffee? Nah, I gotta go.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What's wrong, Stephen?  C'mon, you only beat up the roof when something's on your mind.  How's Brian doing?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: He's out.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I know he's out, but how's he doing?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Y'know, I treated him better than any other probie I ever had. He probably hates my guts, but I did the best thing for him. I made him finally look in the mirror.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Ah Stephen, that's what this is really about, isn't it? You always have to be right.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Hey, I'm the first one to admit when I'm wrong.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yeah? When was the last time?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: In a fire? Never.  Look, I'm his brother. I care about him, y'know? He was going to get himself killed. Maybe not today, maybe not in a year, but it would've happened. And I couldn't -- I just couldn't...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You can't keep being his father...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I'm sorry... I... couldn't sleep...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: I...  It used to be, when I was a kid, what meant most to me about this job was there were no ifs. Life and death, right and wrong. When someone called the fire department, we came... Those guys don't know how much I love them... You don't leave people hanging... cause that's what it's all about. It's loyalty. It's 'till death do us part. Isn't that what you heard?... It's you go, we go... Cause without that, it's the end of families, it's the end of the fire department... and when the fire department stops coming... that's the end of the fucking world...  I'm sorry I came, Helen, it's just... it's just there's nobody I can talk to...  I miss you.

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Cook and I are almost finished here. Have a seat.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stephen... I... can I talk to you a second...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry I --

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: -- No, that's okay. It's just Sean...

turns.speaker: STEPHEN
turns.text: -- He's gettin' good on those eggs. And y'know, he told me he actually likes the piano.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I don't want to confuse him, Stephen.

turns.speaker: RICCO
turns.text: They ran the residue you scraped from both crispers' front doors. It's a combination of plumber's putty and rayophene gum. Burns almost completely away when you light it.

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: Putty? On both doors?

turns.speaker: RICCO
turns.text: There's something else kinda interesting...

turns.speaker: RICCO
turns.text: Anyway, down here, take a look...

turns.speaker: SHADOW
turns.text: McCaffrey, hold this for us.
